> --- Kent Beck wrote:
>> Thank you for the clear example. It seems to me that you can
>> do this kind of validation in a @BeforeClass in JUnit 4.
>> Would that solve your problem?

--- Jason Rogers <jacaetevha@f...> wrote:
> Not so easily in this case.  This is a validation that is
> run before any other test in the AllTests suite, if it fails
> no other test is run.  You get a single failure, fix the
> web.xml file and then run again.  In order to get this same
> behavior in JUnit4 I would have to duplicate the @BeforeClass
> and @AfterClass annotations into every TestCase.  Annotations
> in this sense are really starting to sound like Advices in
> the AOP world.
> 
> Similarly, we have functional tests that use a type of
> validation like the one I mentioned before [...].  The
> validation checks the WSDL [...].  If they don't match
> [...then...] running the tests don't make too much sense,
> so we throw a failure and refuse to run any other tests.  [...]

Good points.

Something I've done to switch banks of tests on and off is to have 
them all inherit from a new class that is a child of TestCase, and 
then I can override 'run(...)', 'runBare()' or 'runTest()' to check 
a flag and then runs the test (by calling the super class TestCase 
implementation) or skips is.  In this case, I might put the test in 
the 'setUp' method of the new base class  (if I'm confident that all 
child class setUp methods call their superclass setUp method!  ;-)  
and set a static flag to indicate if the "before all tests" check 
was done, and another flag to indicate if it was successful or not.  
(If it was run, but it was not successful, then I don't want to run 
the tests.)

I've used this primarily to support configuration flags like "run 
the tests that connect to the database" (or not) and "run the really 
time-consuming tests" (or not).  When doing this, I typically also 
override the constructor and 'setName' method, to call a static 
function that modifies the test case name to show that it's not 
being run.  I'll change "testThis" to "- NOT RUN -  testThis", for 
example, for test cases I will chose not to run.  This trick may not 
be as useful in your case; I'm doing selective disabling of just 
some of the tests.
